title: Why are the last two lines in a poem repeated? - Quora

response.answer_text: IMO uneducated opinion… I think Frost may well have wanted to emphasize, in addition to what precedes the last two lines, same words repeated - “Miles to go before I sleep”, that: 1.) He wanted to really emphasize that he, like many of us may feel, we have many things we would like “to do” and finalize before we die, thus the repetition drives home this point…. -or- 2. They may point to 2 meanings… perhaps: Two different types of accomplishments or experiences he wishes to do before he “sheds this mortal coil” though he didn’t write these particular words… I just thought I’d throw them in. :-) p.s. I was unable to find who, when, and where the “shed this mortal coil” wording was first written and to whom it is attributed… as well as if in poetry, prose, or on a sidewalk? Just thought I’d mention this coil-y thing. :-) p.p.s. - OK, so I’m Not a Poet and I Really Know it. (rephrased a little…)

It provides a sense of closure. It's for the same reason that Shakespeare often rhymes the last two lines of a blank-verse scene, for that sense of finality. For I have promises to keep And miles to go before I sleep And miles to go before I sleep. By repeating the last line, Frost not only gives strong closure to the poem, but also gives enormous weight to the repeated line. It becomes the root of the whole poem, the thing we have been digging for.
